docs.title: 0.4 Using Symbols
docs.text:
1. Never start a sentence with a symbol.
  2. Begin sentences with words, not symbols (e.g., "The equation x² − 6x + 8 = 0 has two distinct roots").
  3. Separate symbols with words if possible.
  4. Add words between symbols to improve clarity (e.g., “the number b”).
  5. Avoid using logic symbols in formal writing.
  6. Refrain from symbols like ⇒, ∀, ∃, except when discussing logic.
  7. Be cautious with i.e. and e.g.
  8. Prefer writing out “that is” or “for example” to avoid confusion.
  9. Write small integers as words.
  10. Use words for small numbers or when describing (e.g., “two groups of order 4”).
  11. Don’t mix words and symbols improperly.
  12. Avoid combining words and symbols (e.g., write “Every integer exceeding 1”).
  13. Avoid unnecessary symbols in theorem statements.
  14. Only introduce symbols when essential in proofs.
  15. Define all symbols.
  16. Explain any introduced symbols (e.g., specify k is an integer in n = 2k + 1).
  17. Use “frozen symbols” correctly.
  18. Maintain standard uses (e.g., m and n for integers, A and B for sets).
  19. Use consistent symbols.
  20. Choose symbols that fit together logically (e.g., avoid switching between a, r, and b unnecessarily).
